revision.text:
{{redirect|Sinosphere}} {{other uses|Greater China}} {{Chinese |title = Sinosphere |pic = East_Asian_Cultural_Sphere.png |picsize = 260px |order = ts |t = 東亞文化圈 |s = 东亚文化圈 |p = Dōngyà wénhuà quān |j = dung1 aa3 man4 faa3 hyun1 |wuu = ton-ia ven-ho-chioe |poj = Tang-a bûn-huà-khian |h = dung24 a31 vun11 fa55 kien24 |kanji = 東亜文化圏 |hiragana = とうあぶんかけん |romaji = |revhep = tō-a bunkaken |kunrei = Tou-A Bunkaken |hanja = 東亞文化圈 |hangul = 동아문화권 |rr = Dong-a Munhwagwon
Dong-a Munhwagwon |qn = Vùng văn hóa Đông Á |hn = 塳文化東亞 }} [[File:漢字文化圈／汉字文化圈 · 한자 문화권 · Vòng văn hóa chữ Hán · 漢字文化圏.svg|thumb|"Chinese character (Hànzì) cultural sphere" and "East Asia Cultural sphere" written in Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Vietnamese.]] [[File:Red Japanese temple (Unsplash).jpg|thumb|[[Mahayana|Mahayana Buddhism]], Influenced East Asian Religion. ]] [[File:Confucius Statue at the Confucius Temple.jpg|thumb|[[Confucianism]] plays a crucial part in East Asian Culture. ]] [[File:Ngomon2.jpg|alt=|thumb|Chinese Architecture has had a major influence, on the East Asian architectural styles of [[Korean architecture|Korea]], [[Vietnamese architecture|Vietnam]], and [[Japanese architecture|Japan]]. Image: [[Imperial City, Huế|Imperial City Hue Vietnam]]]] [[File:Chinese Dragon 2012.jpg|alt=|thumb|East Asian Dragons are legendary creatures in East Asian Mythology and East Asian Culture.]] [[File:Constellation of Literature pavilion - Temple of Literature, Hanoi - DSC04688.JPG|thumb|[[Imperial examination|Confucian Education and Imperial Examaminations]], played a huge role in creating Scholors and [[Mandarin (bureaucrat)|Mandarins]] for East Asian Dynasties. Image: [[Temple of Literature, Hanoi]] ]] {{Contains Vietnamese text}} The "'''East Asian cultural sphere'''" or "'''Sinosphere'''", refers to a grouping of countries and regions in [[East Asia]] that were historically influenced by the [[Chinese culture]]. Other names for the concept include the '''Sinic world''', the '''Confucian world''', the '''Taoist world''', and the '''Chinese cultural sphere''', though the last is also used to refer particularly to the '''[[Sinophone]] world''': the areas which speak [[varieties of Chinese]]. The [[East Asia]]n cultural sphere shares a Confucian ethical philosophy, [[Buddhism]], [[Taoism]] and, historically, a [[Adoption of Chinese literary culture|common writing system]]. The core regions of the East Asian cultural sphere are [[Mainland China]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Macau]], [[Taiwan]], [[North Korea]], [[South Korea]], [[Japan]], and [[Vietnam]]. The terms East Asian cultural sphere and "''Chinese character ([[Chinese character|Hànzì]]) cultural sphere''" are used interchangeably with "''Sinosphere''" but have different denotations. == Academic usage == === Arnold J. Toynbee === The British historian [[Arnold J. Toynbee]] listed the Far Eastern civilization as one of the main civilizations outlined in his book, ''A Study of History''. He included Japan and Korea in his Far Eastern civilization, and proposed that it grew out of the Sinic civilization that originated in the [[Yellow River]] basin.{{cite book |first = Lung-kee |last = Sun |title = The Chinese National Character: From Nationalhood to Individuality |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=O9_U-XdJ3iYC&pg=PA154 |year=2002 |publisher = M.E. Sharpe |ISBN =978-0-7656-3936-3 |page = 154}} Toynbee compared the relationship between the Sinic and Far Eastern civilization with that of the Hellenic and Western civilizations. According to Toynbee, the Hellenic and Western civilizations had an "apparentation-affiliation" relationship, while the Far Eastern world was controlled by the "ghost" of the "Sinic universal state."{{cite book |first = Lung-kee |last = Sun |title=The Chinese National Character: From Nationalhood to Individuality |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=0ZgRtzGLG_oC&pg=PA188 |year=2002 |publisher = M.E. Sharpe |ISBN = 978-0-7656-0826-0 |page = 188}} === Nishijima Sadao === The Japanese historian Nishijima Sadao ({{Interlanguage link multi|西嶋定生|ja}}, 1919–1998) conceived a Chinese or East Asian cultural sphere largely isolated from other cultures. According to Nishijima, this cultural sphere shared the philosophy of Confucianism, the religion of Buddhism, and similar political and social structures. His cultural sphere includes China, Japan, Korea, Vietnam, and areas between Mongolia and the Himalayas.Wang Hui, "'Modernity and 'Asia' in the Study of Chinese History," in Eckhardt Fuchs, Benedikt Stuchtey, eds.,''Across cultural borders: historiography in global perspective'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=4wtBb5sWLyYC&pg=PA322] (Rowman & Littlefield, 2002 {{ISBN|978-0-7425-1768-4}}), p. 322. === Edwin O. Reischauer === The American [[Sinologist]] and historian [[Edwin O. Reischauer]] grouped China, Korea, and Japan together into a cultural sphere that he called the Sinic world. These countries are centralized states that share a Confucian ethical philosophy. Reischauer states that this culture originated in Northern China, and compared the relationship between Northern China and East Asia to that of Greco-Roman civilization and Europe. The elites of East Asia were tied together through a common written language based on Chinese characters, much in the way that [[Latin]] had functioned in Europe.Edwin O. Reischauer, "The Sinic World in Perspective," ''Foreign Affairs ''52.2 (January 1974): 341-348. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/20038053 JSTOR] === Samuel P. Huntington === The American political scientist [[Samuel P. Huntington]] considered the Sinic world as one of many civilizations in his ''[[The Clash of Civilizations]]''. He notes that "all scholars recognize the existence of either a single distinct Chinese civilization dating back to at least 1500 B.C. and perhaps a thousand years earlier, or of two Chinese civilizations one succeeding the other in the early centuries of the Christian epoch." He comments that he originally used the term "Confucian", but "Sinic" is more accurate because it describes "the common culture of China and the Chinese communities in Southeast Asia and elsewhere outside of China as well as the related cultures of Vietnam and Korea."''The Clash of Civilizations and the Remaking of World Order.'' (New York: Simon & Schuster, 1996; {{ISBN|0684811642}}), [https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=Iq75qmi3Og8C&oi=fnd&pg=PR2&dq=sinic+world+-sonic&ots=my_p7oseo6&sig=tT3szdeSMK6c7T5XMbZpYcxOms8#v=onepage&q=sinic%20world%20-sonic&f=false p. 45] Huntington's Sinic civilization includes China, North Korea, South Korea, Mongolia, Taiwan, Vietnam, and Chinese communities in Southeast Asia.{{cite book |author=William E. Davis |title=Peace And Prosperity in an Age of Incivility |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=w1okRtHKiLIC&pg=PA197 |year=2006 |publisher=University Press of America |ISBN = 978-0-7618-3248-5 |page=197}} Of the many civilizations that Huntington discusses, the Sinic world is the only one that is based on a cultural, rather than religious, identity.{{cite book |author = Michail S. Blinnikov |title = A Geography of Russia and Its Neighbors |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=QcoodEOmnMUC&pg=PA132 |year=2011 |publisher=Guilford Press |ISBN = 978-1-60623-933-9 |page=132}} Huntington's theory was that in a post-[[Cold War]] world, humanity "identify with cultural groups: tribes, ethnic groups, religious communities, and at the broadest level, civilizations."{{cite book |author = Lung-kee Sun |title = The Chinese National Character: From Nationalhood to Individuality |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=0ZgRtzGLG_oC&pg=PA32 |year=2002 |publisher=M.E. Sharpe |ISBN = 978-0-7656-0826-0 |page = 32}} He portrayed the cultural sphere's political culture as one with "little room for social or political pluralism and the division of power" with "international politics as hierarchical because their domestic policies are." Huntington argued that the Sinic world would eventually oppose the West's hegemony in Asia, likely through forming an alliance with the Islamic world.{{cite book |author=Hugh Gusterson|title=People of the bomb: portraits of America's nuclear complex |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iHJRW0GI31MC&pg=PA124 |year=2004 |publisher=U of Minnesota Press |ISBN = 978-0-8166-3860-4 |page=124}} == Cultural commonalities== === Architecture === {{Main|Chinese architecture}} Countries from the East Asian cultural sphere share a common architectural style stemming from the architecture of ancient China.https://books.google.com/books?id=tA_3y2XsMMsC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false === Philosophy and religions === {{Main|East Asian religions|Eastern philosophy#East Asian philosophies}} '''Buddhism''' {{Main|East Asian Buddhism}} The countries of China, Japan, Korea, and Vietnam share a history of Mahayana Buddhism. '''Taoism''' {{Main|Taoism}} The countries of China, Japan, Korea, and Vietnam have been influenced by Taoism. ==== Confucianism ==== {{Main|Confucianism}} The countries of China, Japan, Korea, and Vietnam share a Confucian philosophical worldview. Confucianism is a [[humanism|humanistic]]{{cite book |title=Religion in global civil society |last= Juergensmeyer |first= Mark |year= 2005|publisher= Oxford University Press|location= |ISBN = 978-0-19-518835-6 |page = 70}} philosophy that believes that human beings are teachable, improvable and perfectible through personal and communal endeavour especially including self-cultivation and self-creation. Confucianism focuses on the cultivation of virtue and maintenance of ethics, the most basic of which are ''[[Ren (Confucianism)|rén]]'' ({{lang|zh|仁}}), ''[[Yi (Confucianism)|yì]]'' ({{lang|zh|义}}/{{lang|zh|義}}), and ''[[Li (Confucian)|lǐ]]'' ({{lang|zh|礼}}/{{lang|zh|禮}}).[[Edward Craig (philosopher)|Craig, Edward]]. ''Philosophy: A Very Short Introduction''. {{ISBN|0-19-285421-6}} {{Harvnb|Craig|1998|p=536}}. ''Ren'' is an obligation of [[altruism]] and humaneness for other individuals, ''yi'' is the upholding of righteousness and the moral disposition to do good, and ''li'' is a system of norms and propriety that determines how a person should properly act in everyday life. ==== Neo-Confucianism ==== {{Main|Neo-Confucianism}} [[Mid-Imperial China|Mid-Imperial Chinese]] philosophy is primarily defined by the development of [[Neo-Confucianism]]. During the [[Tang Dynasty]], [[Buddhism]] from India also became a prominent philosophical and religious discipline. Neo-Confucianism has its origins in the [[Tang Dynasty]]; the Confucianist scholar [[Han Yu]] is seen as a forebear of the Neo-Confucianists of the Song Dynasty.''Essentials of Neo-Confucianism: Eight Major Philosophers of the Song and Ming Periods'' by Huang, Siu-chi. {{Harvnb|Huang|1999|p=5}}. The Song Dynasty philosopher [[Zhou Dunyi]] is seen as the first true "pioneer" of Neo-Confucianism, using Daoist metaphysics as a framework for his ethical philosophy.''A Sourcebook of Chinese Philosophy'' by Chan, Wing-tsit. {{Harvnb|Chan|2002|p=460}}. Elsewhere in East Asia, [[Japanese philosophy]] began to develop as indigenous [[Shinto]] beliefs fused with [[Buddhism]], [[Confucianism]] and other schools of [[Chinese philosophy]]. Similar to Japan, in [[Korean philosophy]] elements of [[Korean Shamanism|Shamanism]] were integrated into the [[Korean Confucianism|Neo-Confucianism]] imported from China. In Vietnam, neo-Confucianism was developed into Vietnamese own Tam giáo as well, along with indigenous Vietnamese beliefs and [[Mahayana Buddhism]]. === Literary culture === {{Main|Adoption of Chinese literary culture}} East Asian literary culture was based on the use of [[Literary Chinese]], which became the medium of scholarship and government across the region. Although each of these countries developed vernacular writing systems and used them for popular literature, they continued to use Chinese for all formal writing until it was swept away by rising nationalism around the end of the 19th century.{{citation |chapter = A transnational approach to East Asian book history | pages = 65–79 |first = P.F. |last = Kornicki |authorlink = Peter Kornicki |title = New Word Order: Transnational Themes in Book History |editor1-first = Swapan |editor1-last = Chakravorty |editor2-first = Abhijit |editor2-last = Gupta |publisher = Worldview Publications |year = 2011 |ISBN = 978-81-920651-1-3 |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=bjJBrKfCKIYC&pg=PA65 |postscript = .}}{{Harvnb|Kornicki|2011|pp=75–77}} Throughout East Asia, Literary Chinese was the language of administration and scholarship. Although Vietnam, Korea and Japan each developed writing systems for their own languages, these were limited to popular literature. Chinese remained the medium of formal writing until it was displaced by vernacular writing in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.{{sfnp|Kornicki|2011|pp=66–67}} Though they did not use Chinese for spoken communication, each country had its own tradition of reading texts aloud, the so-called [[Sino-Xenic pronunciations]], which provide clues to the pronunciation of [[Middle Chinese]]. Chinese words with these pronunciations were also borrowed extensively into the local vernaculars, and today comprise over half their vocabularies.{{sfnp|Miyake|2004|pp=98–99}} Books in Literary Chinese were widely distributed. By the 7th century and possibly earlier, [[woodblock printing]] had been developed in China. At first, it was used only to copy the Buddhist scriptures, but later secular works were also printed. By the 13th century, metal [[movable type]] used by government printers in Korea, but seems not to have been extensively used in China, Vietnam or Japan. At the same time manuscript reproduction remained important until the late 19th century.{{sfnp|Kornicki|2011|p=68}} === Economics === The [[commerce|business]] cultures of Sinosphere countries remain heavily influenced by Confucianism. Japan features hierarchically-organized [[company|companies]] and the Japanese place a high value on [[interpersonal relationship|relationship]]s{{cite book | title = Where cultures meet; a cross-cultural comparison of business meeting styles | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=JUyRNpVtt5oC&pg=PA69 |publisher= Hogeschool van Amsterdam |ISBN = 978-90-79646-17-3 |page= 69}} (see [[Japanese work environment]]). Korean [[business]]es also adhere to Confucian values, and are structured around a [[patriarchy|patriarchal]] family governed by filial piety between management and a company's employees.{{cite book | author1= Timothy Book |author2= Hy V.. Luong |title = Culture and economy: the shaping of capitalism in eastern Asia |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=AR3arRgfltkC&pg=PA131 |accessdate = 26 May 2013|year= 1999 |publisher= University of Michigan Press |ISBN = 978-0-472-08598-9 |page = 131}} East Asia became an area of economic power starting with the [[Meiji Restoration]] in the late 19th century when Japan rapidly transformed itself into the only industrial power outside the North Atlantic area.{{cite book |author= Aiko Ikeo |title = Economic Development in Twentieth-Century East Asia: The International Context |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=4wI02db8VtwC&pg=PA12 |date = 4 January 2002 |publisher= Taylor & Francis |ISBN = 978-0-203-02704-2 |page = 12}} Japan's early industrial economy reached its height in [[World War II]] (1939-1945) when it expanded its empire and became a major world power. Following Japanese defeat and economic collapse after the war, Japan's economy recovered in the 1950s with the [[Japanese post-war economic miracle|post-war economic miracle]] in which rapid growth propelled the country to become the world's second largest economy by the 1980s. In the late 20th century and early 21st century, South Korea and China have become the 11th- and 2nd-largest economies in the world respectively, according to nominal GDP. Vietnamese commerce is also heavily influenced by Chinese methods, with some French methods (due to French colonialism). Vietnam, one of [[Jim O'Neill, Baron O'Neill of Gatley#Next Eleven|Next Eleven]] countries {{as of | 2005 | lc = on}}, is regarded{{by whom|date=August 2017}} as a rising [[Power (international relations)|power]] in Southeast Asia. The then [[British Hong Kong|British colony of Hong Kong]] became one of the [[Four Asian Tigers|Four Asian Tiger]] economies, developing strong textile and manufacturing economies.Compare: {{cite book | author1 = J. James W. Harrington |author2= Barney Warf |title = Industrial Location: Principles, Practice, and Policy |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=NBKjj5Wq6N0C&pg=PA199 |year= 1995 |publisher= Routledge |ISBN = 978-0-415-10479-1 |page = 199 | quote = As the textile industry began to abandon places with high labor costs in the western industrialized world, it began to sprout up in a variety of Third World locations, in particular the famous 'Four Tiger' nations of East Asia: South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Singapore. Textiles were particularly important in the early industrialization of South Korea, while garment production was more significant to Hong Kong.}} South Korea followed a similar route, developing a textile industry. Following in the footsteps of Hong Kong and Korea, Taiwan and [[Singapore]] quickly industrialized through government policies. By 1997 the four Asian Tiger economies joined Japan as East Asia's developed economies. Present{{when|date=August 2017}} growth in East Asia has now shifted to China and to the [[Tiger Cub Economies]] of Southeast Asia.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} === Cuisine === {{Main|East Asian cuisine}} The cuisine of East Asia shares many of the same ingredients and techniques. Chopsticks are used as an eating utensil in all of the core East Asian countries.{{cite book |first = Alan |last = Davidson |title = Food in Motion: The Migration of Foodstuffs and Cookery Techniques : Proceedings : Oxford Symposium 1983 |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=zcNdB_sl2JkC&pg=PA22 |year=1981 |publisher=Oxford Symposium |ISBN = 978-0-907325-07-9 |page=22}} The use of soy sauce, a sauce made from fermenting soy beans, is also widespread in East Asia. Rice is a main staple food in all of East Asia and is a major focus of [[food security]].{{cite book |author1 = Wen S. Chern |author2 = Colin A. Carter |author3=Shun-yi Shei |title = Food security in Asia: economics and policies |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=zcOmGXTqYWMC&pg=PA2 |year=2000 |publisher = Edward Elgar Publishing |ISBN = 978-1-78254-334-3 |page=2}} In East Asian countries, the word for 'cooked rice' can embody the meaning of food in general ([[simplified Chinese]]: {{lang|zh-hans|饭}}; [[traditional Chinese]]: {{lang|zh-hant|飯}}; [[pinyin]]: {{audio|Zh-fàn.ogg|fàn|help=no}}). === Chinese characters === {{main|Chinese characters}} Historically China, Japan, Korea, and Vietnam have used Chinese characters. Today they are mainly used in China, Taiwan, Japan, and South Korea to a limited extent (i.e. scholarly papers, newspapers, etc.), albeit in different forms. Although Chinese characters have become almost obsolete in Vietnam and North Korea, they still hold a special place in the cultures as their history and literature have been greatly influenced by Chinese characters; Chinese characters can be seen in temples, cemeteries, and monuments today, as well as serving as decorative motifs in art and design. === New Year === {{Main|Lunar New Year}} China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and Vietnam traditionally observe the same lunar new year. However, Japan has moved its New Year to fit the Western New Year since the [[Meiji Restoration]] while Korea later also moved to Western New Year since 1970s. == Etymology of Sinosphere and related terms == The term Sinosphere is sometimes used as a synonym for the East Asian cultural sphere. The [[etymology]] of ''{{linktext|Sinosphere}}'' is from ''{{linktext|Sino-}}'' "China; Chinese" (cf. [[Sinophone]]) and ''{{linktext|-sphere}}'' in the sense of "[[sphere of influence]]", "area influenced by a country". The "[[CJK]]V" languages – Chinese, Japanese, Korean and Vietnamese – translate the English ''-sphere'' as Chinese ''quān'' {{lang|zh|{{linktext|圈}}}} "circle; ring; corral; pen",DeFrancis, John, ed. (2003), ''ABC Chinese-English Comprehensive Dictionary'', University of Hawaii Press, p. 750. Japanese ''ken'' "sphere; circle; range; radius",T. Watanabe, E. R. Skrzypczak, and P. Snowden (2003), ''[[Kenkyūsha's New Japanese-English Dictionary]]'', Kenkyusha, p. 873. Compare [[Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere]]. Korean ''gwon''{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} and Vietnamese ''quyển''. [[Victor H. Mair]] discussed the origins of these "culture sphere" terms.Victor Mair, [http://languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu/nll/?p=4306 Sinophone and Sinosphere], [[Language Log]], November 8, 2012. Chinese ''{{transl|zh|wénhuà quān}}'' {{lang|zh|文化圈}} dates back to a 1941 translation for German ''[[Kulturkreis]]'' "culture circle/field", which the Austrian [[ethnologists]] [[Fritz Graebner]] and [[Wilhelm Schmidt (linguist)|Wilhelm Schmidt]] proposed. The Japanese historian {{nihongo|Nishijima Sadao|西嶋定生||1919-1998}}, professor emeritus at the [[University of Tokyo]], coined the expressions {{nihongo|''Kanji bunka ken''|漢字文化圏||"Chinese-character culture sphere"}} and {{nihongo|''Chuka bunka ken''|中華文化圏||"Chinese culture sphere"}}, which Chinese later borrowed as [[loanwords]]. Nishijima devised these Sinitic "cultural spheres" within his {{nihongo|"Theory of an East Asian World"|東アジア世界論|Higashi Ajia sekai-ron}}. Chinese-English dictionaries give similar translations of this keyword ''{{transl|zh|wénhuà quān}}'' {{lang|zh|文化圈}}: "the intellectual or literary circles" ([[Liang Shiqiu]] 1975), "literary, educational circle(s)" ([[Lin Yutang]] 1972), and "intellectual/literary circles" ([[John DeFrancis]] 1996). This cultural region closely corresponds to the [[History of China#Ancient China|ancient "Sinic civilization"]] and its descendants, the "Far Eastern civilizations" (the Mainland and the Japanese ones), which [[Arnold J. Toynbee]] presented in the 1930s in ''[[A Study of History]]'', along with the [[Western world|Western]], Islamic, Eastern Orthodox, Indic, etc. civilizations, among the major "units of study" of the world's history.See the "family tree" of Toynbee's "civilizations" in any edition of Toynbee's own work, or e.g. as Fig.1 on p.16 of: ''The Rhythms of History: A Universal Theory of Civilizations'', By Stephen Blaha. Pingree-Hill Publishing, 2002. {{ISBN|0-9720795-7-2}}. == See also == {{Portal|Culture|Asia|China|Japan|Korea|Hong Kong|Macau|Taiwan|Vietnam|International relations}} * [[Sinosphere (linguistics)]] * [[Adoption of Chinese literary culture]] * [[East Asia]] * [[Sinophone|Sinophone world]] * [[Sino-Xenic pronunciations|Sinoxenic]] *[[Chinese culture|Culture of China]] *[[Culture of Korea]] *[[Culture of Japan]] *[[Culture of Taiwan]] *[[Culture of Vietnam]] == References == === Citations === {{Reflist}} === Sources === {{refbegin}} * {{cite book |last = Ankerl |first = Guy |series = Global communication without universal civilization |volume = 1 |title = Coexisting contemporary civilizations : Arabo-Muslim, Bharati, Chinese, and Western |publisher = INU Press |location = Geneva, Switzerland |ISBN = 2-88155-004-5 |pages = |date= 2000 }} * Joshua Fogel, "The Sinic World," in [[Ainslie Thomas Embree]], [[Carol Gluck]], ed., ''Asia in Western and World History a Guide for Teaching.'' (Armonk, N.Y.: M.E. Sharpe, Columbia Project on Asia in the Core Curriculum, 1997). {{ISBN|0585027331}}. Access may be limited to NetLibrary affiliated libraries. [http://www.netlibrary.com/urlapi.asp?action=summary&v=1&bookid=1603] * {{cite book |last1=Fogel |first1=Joshua A. |title = Articulating the Sinosphere : Sino-Japanese relations in space and time |date=2009 |publisher = Harvard University Press |location = Cambridge, Mass. |series=Edwin O. Reischauer Lectures |ISBN = 0-674-03259-4 |edition = [Online-Ausg.] }} * {{cite book |last1 = Holcombe |first1 = Charles |title = A history of East Asia : from the origins of civilization to the twenty-first century |date = 2011 |publisher = Cambridge University Press |location = Cambridge, England |ISBN = 978-0521731645 |edition = 1st published. |pages = 1–10 |chapter = Introduction: What is East Asia |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=rHeb7wQu0xIC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Holcombe+History+of+East+Asia&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6j-lUaHTC8GzyQHM84GICQ&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Introduction%3A%20What%20is%20East%20Asia%3F&f=false}} * {{cite book |last1 = Holcombe |first1=Charles |title = The Genesis of East Asia, 221 B.C.-A.D. 907 |date=2001 |publisher = Association for Asian Studies and University of Hawai'i Press |location=Honolulu |ISBN = 0824824156 |edition = [Online-Ausg.] }} * {{cite journal |last1=Reischauer |first1=Edwin O. |title = The Sinic World in Perspective |journal = Foreign Affairs |date=1974 |volume=52 |issue=2 |pages=341–348 |doi = 10.2307/20038053 |jstor = 20038053}} {{refend}} == External links == * [http://afe.easia.columbia.edu/ Asia for Educators]. Weatherhead East Asian Institute, Columbia University. {{East Asian topics}} {{Use dmy dates |date = April 2011}} [[Category:Chinese culture]] [[Category:Chinese nationalism]] [[Category:Country classifications]] [[Category:Cultural regions]] [[Category:East Asian culture| ]] [[Category:Foreign relations of China]] [[Category:Japanese culture]] [[Category:Korean culture]] [[Category:Vietnamese culture]]

{{for|the Ukrainian bank|First Investment Bank (PJSC)}} {{Expand Bulgarian|Първа инвестиционна банка|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox company |name = First Investment Bank
Първа инвестиционна банка |type = [[Private company|Private]] |logo = First Investment Bank.svg |foundation = {{start date and age|1993|10|08|df=yes}} |location = [[Sofia]], [[Bulgaria]] |industry = [[Financial services]] |products = [[Retail banking|Retail]], [[private bank|private]] and [[Commercial bank|corporate banking]] |assets = €4438.04 mln (2015)[https://thebanks.eu/banks/10753 Bank Profile: First Investment Bank] |equity = €381.19 mln (2015) |homepage = [http://www.fibank.bg/en First Investment Bank] }} '''First Investment Bank''' or Fibank ({{lang-bg|Първа инвестиционна банка}}, ''Parva investitsionna banka''), founded on 8 October 1993, is currently (Q1'13) the third largest [[Bulgaria]]n bank (measured in total assets). The bank is the mother bank of a financial group on the [[Balkans]] - it has a branch in [[Albania]] with 10 offices, one in [[Cyprus]], as well as a subsidiary bank in Macedonia ({{lang-bg|УНИБанка}}, ''UNIBank''). First Investment Bank also controls CaSys International - an international card operator based in [[Skopje]], [[Republic of Macedonia]]. In Bulgaria, it has 21 branches and 68 offices throughout the country. Its clients include 380,000 individuals and 21,000 corporate bodies. ==See also== * [[List of banks in Bulgaria]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.fibank.bg/en First Investment Bank website] * [http://www.unibank.com.mk/index.php?language=38 UNIBank website] * [http://www.fibank.al/index.php?language=38 First Investment Bank Albania website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090417182243/http://www.casys.com.mk/index.php?language=38 CaSys International] [[Category:1993 establishments in Bulgaria]] [[Category:Banks of Bulgaria]] [[Category:Banks established in 1993]] [[Category:Companies based in Sofia]] [[Category:Bulgarian brands]] {{Europe-bank-stub}} {{Bulgaria-stub}}

revision.text: {{Update|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox airline | airline=Flying Dragon Airlines | image= | caption= | IATA= | ICAO= | callsign= | founded= | commenced= | ceased= | bases= | fleet_size=See [[#Fleet|Fleet]] below | destinations=See [[#Services|Services]] below | parent=Feilong Aviation | headquarters=[[Nepalgunj]], Nepal }} '''Flying Dragon Airlines''' was an [[airline]] based at [[Nepalgunj Airport]] in [[Nepal]]. == History == The [[Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal]] granted Flying Dragon Airlines an air operators certificate in 2005. The airline was required to be based in [[Nepalgunj]].[http://www.hotelnepal.com/nepal_news.php?id=665 Hotelnepal.com] retrieved 19 November 2006 Chinese aviation company [[China Flying Dragon Aviation]], based in [[Harbin]], partly owns Flying Dragon Airlines.{{cite web|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2005-06-13/news/27482032_1_singapore-airlines-cargo-sia-cargo-passenger-and-cargo-services|title=Flying Dragon to operate in Nepal|work=The Economic Times|accessdate=3 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/nepals-commercial-aviation-set-to-grow-200922/|title=Nepal’s commercial aviation set to grow|author=Reed Business Information Limited|publisher=|accessdate=3 January 2015}} The airline was due to launch in September 2005, using [[Harbin Y-12|Y-12]] 17-seater dual passenger/cargo aircraft.[http://www.chinanews.cn/news/2004/2005-06-08/5683.shtml China News] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061011081604/http://www.chinanews.cn/news/2004/2005-06-08/5683.shtml |date=2006-10-11 }} 8 June 2005 == Services == Flying Dragon Airlines is authorised to operate services to the following destinations:[http://www.caanepal.org.np/airtransportation4.htm CAAN] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060518132458/http://www.caanepal.org.np/airtransportation4.htm |date=2006-05-18 }} retrieved 19 November 2006{{cite web|url=http://www.hotelnepal.com/news.php?id=533|title=Flying Dragon Airlines granted license CAAN|publisher=|accessdate=3 January 2015}} [[Nepalgunj]], [[Dolpa]], [[Surkhet]], [[Jumla (town)|Jumla]], [[Lukla]], [[Rukum]], [[Jomsom]], [[Simikot]] and [[Kathmandu]]. == Fleet == The airline intended to operate three [[Harbin Y-12]]. According to PlaneLogger.com, only two were delivered and only one remains in the fleet.{{cite web|url=http://www.planelogger.com/Airline/Fleet/Flying%20Dragon%20Airlines|title=Flying Dragon Airlines - Fleet - PlaneLogger|publisher=|accessdate=3 January 2015}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{Airlines of Nepal}} [[Category:Airlines of Nepal]] {{Asia-airline-stub}} {{Nepal-transport-stub}}

{{about|the place|the root vegetable Gajar|Carrot}} [[File:Gajary-hlavna-kostol.jpg|thumb|250px|Main street with the church]]
'''Gajary''' ({{lang-de|Gayring}}) is a [[village]] and [[municipality]] in western [[Slovakia]] close to the town of [[Malacky]] in the [[Bratislava region]]. It lies around 40 km (25 statute miles) north-west of Slovakia's capital [[Bratislava]] close to the Austrian border. The village has around 3500 inhabitants.
The village is an important archaeological site: findings from the [[Neolithic]] period, [[Eneolithic]] period, [[Bronze Age]], early [[Slavs|Slavic]] period (several Slavic settlements) have been excavated there. Ing. Ján Kubíček (1922–2003) former head of Finance at Slovakia's Ministry of Internal Affairs was born there.
==Names and etymology== The [[Slovak language|Slovak]] name ''Gajary'' (1460 ''Gayary'') comes from [[Germans|German]] personal name [[Geier (surname)|Geier]] (1337 ''Gaywar'', later German name was ''Gairing''). In the 14th century, the village had also the [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] name ''Öregház'' (''Old House'', 1377 ''Eureghaz''), but the name was forgotten and then they used the name of German origin ''Gajár''.<ref name="varsik">{{cite book| first=Branislav | last=Varsik | author-link=Branislav Varsik | title= Z osídlenia západného a stredného Slovenska v stredoveku | publisher = Veda, vydavateľstvo Slovenskej akadémie vied | year = 1984 | location = Bratislava | p=102| language = Slovak}}</ref>
==Genealogical resources==
The records for genealogical research are available at the state archive "Statny Archiv in Bratislava, Slovakia"
* Roman Catholic church records (births/marriages/deaths): 1657-1895 (parish A)
==See also== * [[List of municipalities and towns in Slovakia]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== *https://web.archive.org/web/20070513023228/http://www.statistics.sk/mosmis/eng/run.html *[http://www.cisarik.com/0_Gajary_Malacky_BL_Pozsony_Bratislava.html'''Surnames''' of living people in Gajary]
{{Malacky District}}
{{coord|48|27|58|N|16|55|26|E|source:huwiki_region:SK_type:city|display=title}}
{{Authority control}}
[[Category:Villages and municipalities in Malacky District]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox legislature | name = General Council of Andorra | native_name = Consell General d'Andorra
Consell General d'Andorra
Conseil général d'Andorre | transcription_name = | legislature = | coa_pic = Consell General d'Andorra logo.png | coa_res = 260px | house_type = Unicameral | leader1_type = [[List of General Syndics of the General Council of the Valleys (Andorra)|General Syndic]] | leader1 = Francesc Junqueras i Casamajó | party1 = [[Democrats for Andorra|DA]] | election1 = 17 December 2017 | members = 28 | structure1 = 2015 Andorra Parliament Structure.png | structure1_res = 260px | structure1_alt = Current Structure of the General Council of Andorra | political_groups1 = {{color box|#FF8000}} [[Democrats for Andorra]] (15)
{{color box|#0000FF}} [[Liberal Party of Andorra]] (8)
{{color box|#DF0101}} [[Social Democratic Party (Andorra)|Social Democratic Party]] (3)
{{color box|#4C0B5F}} [[Social Democracy and Progress]] (2) | voting_system1 = [[Parallel voting|Parallel Voting]]
*[[Andorran parliamentary election, 2009#Electoral system|14 members by national list PR]] *[[Parishes of Andorra|Two members per parish (Total 14)]] | last_election1 = [[Andorran parliamentary election, 2015|1 March 2015]] | session_room = | session_res = 260px | session_alt = The General Council sits in the Casa de la Vall in Andorra la Vella | meeting_place = [[New Parliament of Andorra]]
[[Andorra la Vella]], [[Andorra]] | website = [http://www.consellgeneral.ad General Council of Andorra] }} {{Catalan-speaking world|image= |expanded=Politics}} {{Politics of Andorra}} The '''General Council''' ({{lang-ca|Consell General d'Andorra}}, {{IPA-ca|kunˈsɛʎ ʒənəˈɾal dənˈdorə|IPA}}) is the [[unicameral]] [[parliament]] of [[Andorra]]. It is sometimes referred to as the '''General Council of the Valleys''' (Catalan: ''Consell General de les Valls'') because it was the historical name and to distinguish it from similarly named bodies in the [[Val d'Aran]] and in [[France]]. ==Organization== There are twenty-eight "general councillors", who are elected for four-year terms based on party lists in a [[closed list]] system:Art. 42.2, Law 28/2007. *two general councillors from each of the seven [[Parishes of Andorra|parishes]], elected from the list with most votes in each parish;Art. 57, Law 28/2007. *fourteen general councillors elected from national lists using the [[largest remainder method]] of [[proportional representation]].Art. 58, Law 28/2007. The parish lists and the national list are independent of one another: the same person cannot appear on both the national list and on a parish list, and voters cast two separate ballots (there is no requirement to vote for the same party for both lists).Arts. 19, 51 & 52, Law 28/2007. This is a recent development; originally, the [[parishes of Andorra|seven parishes]] had each returned four deputies. However, as parishes varied in population from 350 to 2,500, this was felt to be significantly imbalanced, and the national list system was introduced for the 1997 elections to counter the disproportionate power held by the smallest parishes. {{cn|date=June 2012}} The Council appoints a presiding officer, titled the ''Síndic general'', and a deputy, the ''subsíndic''. The current ''Síndic general'' is Vicenç Mateu Zamora of the Democrats for Andorra. The General Council (subject to approval of the [[List of Co-Princes of Andorra|Co-Princes]]) elects the Head of Government, who presides over the Executive Council. The Head of Government appoints the remaining seven members of the Executive Council. The current Head of Government, is [[Antoni Martí]]. ==Membership== {{further|Andorran parliamentary election, 2015}} Political parties are a recent innovation; the first party was formed in 1976, and they only gained legal recognition in 1992. The most recent [[Andorran parliamentary election, 2015|Andorran parliamentary election]] was March 2015. The General Council has the second-highest proportion of women legislators (behind the [[Chamber of Deputies of Rwanda|lower house of the Rwandan legislature]]), and the highest in the developed world. Exactly half of its members (14 out of 28) are women.{{cite web|url=http://www.ipu.org/wmn-e/classif.htm |title=Women in Parliaments: World Classification |publisher=Ipu.org |date=2012-03-31 |accessdate=2012-05-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140328105108/http://www.ipu.org/wmn-e/classif.htm |archivedate=28 March 2014 |df=dmy }} ==History== The first parliament in Andorra was established in 1419, as the ''Consell de la Terra''. Councillors were elected by the population, and the council appointed ''[[syndics]]'' to manage the administration of the principality. It remained in force for several hundred years, slowly becoming the fiefdom of a few major families; this caused popular discontent by the nineteenth century, and major reforms were instituted in 1866.http://www.worldstatesmen.org/andorra_1866.txt The reforms were masterminded by [[Guillem d'Areny-Plandolit]], and had several effects: * The Consell de la Terra was abolished, and replaced by the ''Consell General de las Valls'', with a syndic and vice-syndic * The [[Suffrage|franchise]] was extended to all heads of families * Regular elections were laid down; in this case, twelve of the twenty-four (as there then were) councillors were to be elected every two years In the 1930s, matters again began to boil over; one point of particular contention was that the Council had begun regularly referring to Andorra as a republic, which understandably caused some contention with the co-princes. The General Council was dissolved on their order in June 1933, and a special election called to re-elect it. The opportunity was taken to change the voting laws; at this point, all men over twenty-five could vote, and all men over thirty stand for election. In 1970, the vote was extended to women over twenty-five; in 1971 the qualifying age for all electors was lowered to twenty-one, and that of candidates to twenty-five. Women gained the right to run for office in 1973, and in 1978 a [[referendum]] was held on the matter of further reform. Later that year, a seventh parish ([[Escaldes-Engordany]]) was formed, bringing the numbers of councillors to twenty-eight. In 1982, the Executive Council was created, comprising the Executive Council President and four councillors with ministerial duties. ==See also== *[[List of First Syndics of the General Council of the Valleys (Andorra)]] *[[List of General Syndics of the General Council of the Valleys (Andorra)]] *[[Politics of Andorra]] *[[List of legislatures by country]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.consellgeneral.ad}} {{Europe topic|Parliament of}} {{National unicameral legislatures}} {{coord|42|30|24|N|1|31|15|E|source:kolossus-plwiki|display=title}} [[Category:General Council (Andorra)| ]] [[Category:National legislatures|Andorra]] [[Category:Parliaments by country|Andorra]] {{Andorra-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox musical artist | name = Heróis do Mar | image = | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Portugal]] | genre = [[New wave music|New wave]], [[pop rock]], [[post-punk]],{{cite web|title=Nos 30 anos dos Heróis do Mar|url=http://sound--vision.blogspot.pt/2011/11/nos-30-anos-dos-herois-do-mar-15.html|work=sound + vision|accessdate=23 March 2012|date=21 November 2011}} [[synthpop]] | years_active = {{start date|1981}}–{{end date|1990}} | label = | associated_acts = | website = | current_members = Tozé Almeida
Rui Pregal da Cunha
Paulo Pedro Gonçalves
Pedro Ayres Magalhães
Carlos Maria Trindade | past_members = }} '''Heróis do Mar''' was a [[Portugal|Portuguese]] [[pop rock]] band formed in March 1981. The group was disbanded in 1990.{{cite web|title=Heróis do Mar: documentário em ante-estreia no Porto|url=http://cotonete.clix.pt/noticias/body.aspx?id=33688|work=cotonete|accessdate=21 March 2012|date=2 March 2007}} Their name ''Heróis do Mar'' is taken from the first line of the [[Portuguese national anthem]]. == Members == * Paulo Pedro Gonçalves – guitar * Carlos Maria Trindade – keyboards * Tozé Almeida – drums * Pedro Ayres Magalhães – bass guitar * Rui Pregal da Cunha – vocals, mandolin == Discography == === Studio Albums === * ''Heróis do Mar'' (LP, Polygram, 1981) * ''Mãe'' (LP, Polygram, 1983) * ''O Rapto'' (Mini-LP, Polygram, 1984) * ''Macau'' (LP, EMI, 1986) * ''Heróis do Mar IV'' (LP, EMI, 1988) === Video Albums === * ''Vídeos 1981/1989'' (DVD, EMI, 2011) === Singles === * ''Amor'' (Maxi, Polygram, 1982) * ''Paixão'' (Maxi, Polygram, 1983) * ''Alegria'' (Maxi, Polygram, 1985) * ''Fado'' (Single, EMI, 1986) * ''O Inventor'' (Maxi, EMI, 1987) * ''Eu Quero (Mistura Possessiva)'' (Maxi, EMI, 1988) * ''Africana'' (Maxi, EMI, 1989) == References == {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Herois do Mar (band)}} [[Category:Musical groups established in 1981]] [[Category:Musical groups disestablished in 1990]] [[Category:Portuguese rock music groups]] [[Category:New wave groups]] [[Category:Synthpop groups]] [[Category:1981 establishments in Portugal]] [[Category:1990 disestablishments in Portugal]] {{Europe-band-stub}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | image = Photograph-hope-macpherson-colour-portrait-by-vincent-barclay-552670-large.jpg | name = Hope Black | birth_name = Jessica Hope MacPherson | birth_date = 1919 | death_date = 25.01.2018 | death_place = Victoria Australia | residence = AUS | citizenship = Australian | field = [[Malacology]], [[marine biology]] | work_institution = [[National Museum of Victoria]] | alma_mater = [[University of Melbourne]] | known_for = First female curator at the National Museum of Victoria | author_abbreviation_bot = | author_abbreviation_zoo = | religion = | footnotes = }}
'''Hope Black''' (''née'' MacPherson, 1919 – 25 January 2018) was an Australian scientist, a marine biologist and [[malacologist]].<ref name=":0"/><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://tributes.theage.com.au/obituaries/theage-au/obituary.aspx?n=hope-black&pid=188005579 |title=Hope BLACK's Obituary on The Age |date=30 January 2018 |website=The Age |access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> In 1937 she started working at the National Museum of Victoria. Subsequently she became Curator of Molluscs at the museum in 1946. She was the National Museum's first female curator. When she married in 1965, she was forced to leave the museum, and instead became a science teacher for thirteen years.
==Career== Appointed as Curator of Mollusks in 1946, Hope MacPherson was Australia's first female curator at the [[Museum Victoria|National Museum of Victoria]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://collections.museumvictoria.com.au/articles/8027|title=Hope Black nee Macpherson, Curator of Molluscs (1919-2018)|work=Museums Victoria Collections|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref>
Her tenure was brought to a close prematurely, when in 1965 she married and became Hope Black, requiring her retirement from the Victorian public service as a result of the [[marriage bar]].<ref name=":0" /> Subsequently Black worked for 13 years as a science teacher.<ref name="museumvictoria2">{{cite web|url=http://museumvictoria.com.au/about/mv-blog/mar-2012/hope-black-honoured/ |title=Hope Black honoured |publisher=[[Museum Victoria]] |date= |accessdate=2014-08-14}}</ref>
==Work in marine biology== [[File:Portrait-of-hope-macpherson-museum-victoria-curator-of-molluscs-1946-1965 (public domain).jpg|thumb|left|Portrait of Hope Black (circa 1950s)]] Hope Black was initially employed in 1937 at Museum Victoria by the support of the [[Carnegie Corporation]]. She worked on developing and preparing new display cases for the McCoy Hall [[diorama]]s.<ref name="museumvictoria1919">{{Cite web |url=http://museumvictoria.com.au/collections/themes/8027/hope-black-nee-macpherson-curator-of-molluscs-1919# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2014-08-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140814152446/http://museumvictoria.com.au/collections/themes/8027/hope-black-nee-macpherson-curator-of-molluscs-1919# |archive-date=2014-08-14 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> In 1947 Black collaborated to survey the [[Snowy River]] Gorge on horseback, prior construction of the [[Snowy Mountains Scheme|Snowy Mountains Hydroelectric Scheme]].<ref name="museumvictoria1919"/>
Between 1957-1963, Black carried out biological surveys of [[Port Phillip Bay]], and her results are still used as baseline data from which to measure environmental change in the area.<ref name="museumvictoria2"/>
Black investigated the genus ''[[Teredo (genus)|Teredo]]'', a group of marine bivalve mollusks known as "shipworms". She also surveyed edible [[mollusc]]s in Victoria. Ultimately, her mollusc research lead to her writing the book ''[[Molluscs of Victoria]]'', which was published in 1962.<ref>{{cite book | last = Black | first =Hope | year = 1962 | title = Marine molluscs of Victoria. | location = Melbourne, Australia | publisher=[[Melbourne University Press]] |ref=harv}}</ref>
Notably, Black was also a member of a group of four women (also including [[Isobel Bennett]], Susan Ingham and [[Mary Gillham]]) who were the first to carry out research in the [[sub-Antarctic]] in 1959.<ref name="museumvictoria2"/> She was inducted into the [[Victorian Honour Roll of Women]] in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|last=Morris|first=Deborah|title=Somerville woman named on honour roll|url=https://www.webcitation.org/6RsfyTKt1|newspaper=Frankston Standard Leader|date=9 March 2012}}</ref>
{{-}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.eoas.info/biogs/P003349b.htm Black, Hope (1919 - )], Encyclopedia of Australian Science
{{DEFAULTSORT:Black, Hope}} [[Category:1919 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:Australian women scientists]] [[Category:Australian public servants]] [[Category:University of Melbourne alumni]] [[Category:Scientists from Melbourne]] [[Category:Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:Women Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:Women marine biologists]] [[Category:Marine biologists]] [[Category:Malacologists]]

revision.text:
The '''House of Dănești''' was one of the two main lineages of the [[Wallachia]]n noble family [[House of Basarab]]. They were descended from [[Dan I of Wallachia]]. The other lineage of the Basarabs is the [[House of Drăculești]].
== Members == *[[Dan I of Wallachia]] *[[Dan II of Wallachia]] *[[Vladislav II of Wallachia]] *[[Dan III of Wallachia]] *[[Basarab II of Wallachia]]
==References== *[[Nicolae Iorga]], ''Histoire des Roumains : volume IV, Les chevaliers'', Bucharest, 1937.

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
According to the US Religious Freedom Report of 2006 there are about 2000 North Africans currently living in [[Andorra]] (out of 72,000) and they are the largest Muslim group in the country.<ref>[https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71365.htm Andorra, International Religious Freedom Report 2006]</ref>
==Population== *[[Moroccans]] (515) *[[Turkish people|Turks]] (112) *[[Pakistanis]] (79)
==Institutions== The Muslim community has an Islamic Cultural Center which provides about 50 students with [[Arabic]] lessons. The government and the Muslim community have not yet agreed on a system which would enable the schools to give such lessons.
There is no specifically built [[mosque]] in Andorra and the government refuses to allocate land for such a project, saying there are not enough low-priced lands. In 2003 the local imam, [[Mohamed Raguig]], petitioned Bishop [[Joan Martí Alanis]] asking for either land from the Church in order to build a mosque or for space inside a church to be used as a mosque.<ref>[http://www.arabicnews.com/ansub/Daily/Day/030429/2003042930.html Muslims in Andorra ask for Bishop help to build mosque] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930181453/http://www.arabicnews.com/ansub/Daily/Day/030429/2003042930.html |date=2007-09-30 }}, [[ArabNews]], April 29, 2003</ref>
==History== At around 700, the Muslims conquered the area from the [[Visigoths]], through the [[Segre (river)|Segre]] valley. The Muslims did not really stay in Andorra, rather using it as a shortcut to get to [[Toulouse]], [[Narbonne]], [[Carcassonne]] and [[Nîmes]].
The [[Battle of Tours|Battle of Poitiers]] and the [[Battle of Roncesvalles]] marked the end of those expeditions to the other part of the [[Pyrenees]].
According to [[Antoni Filter i Rossell]] in his history book the [[Manual Digest]] (1748), in 788, 5000 Andorrans, led by [[Marc Almugàver]] came to Charlemagne's assistance in the [[Vall de Carol]] in fighting the Muslims. After the battle, Charlemagne gave his protection to Andorra and declared them as a sovereign people.<ref>[http://www.andorramania.com/histoire_gb.htm Geography and History of the Principality of Andorra]</ref> ==See also== * [[Islam]]
==References== <references />
{{Islam in Europe}}
[[Category:Islam by country|Andorra]] [[Category:Islam in Europe|Andorra]] [[Category:History of Andorra]] [[Category:Religion in Andorra]]
{{Andorra-stub}} {{Islam-country-stub}}

revision.comment: Importing Wikidata [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "state whose primary territory consists of one or more islands or parts of islands" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|state whose primary territory consists of one or more islands or parts of islands}} {{See also|List of island countries}} [[Image:Island nations.svg|thumb|350px|Sovereign states and states with limited recognition fully on islands (Australia is regarded a continent): those with land borders shaded green, and those without shaded dark blue]] An '''island country''' is a [[country]] whose primary territory consists of one or more [[island]]s or parts of islands. As of 2011, 46 (approximately 24%<ref name="Small is Democratic">{{cite book | last = Ott | first = Dan | title = Small is Democratic | publisher = Routledge | year = 1996
| pages = 128 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=JOqZ9eOeRXoC&pg=PA128&dq=%22island+country%22&lr=#PPA128,M1 | isbn = 0-8153-3910-0}}</ref>) of the 193 [[Member states of the United Nations|UN member states]] are island countries.
==Politics== The percentage of island countries that are [[democracy|democratic]] is higher than that of [[wikt:continental#Adjective|continental]] countries. Historically they have been less prone to political instability than their continental counterparts.<ref name="Small is Democratic"/>
==War== Island countries have often been the basis of maritime conquest and historical rivalry between other countries.<ref name="The quest for identity">{{cite news | last = Chasle | first = Raymond | title = The quest for identity. (island countries) | publisher = UNESCO Courier | date = 1 Oct 1986 | url = http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-9197350_ITM | accessdate = 2009-02-01}}</ref> Island countries are more susceptible to attack by large, continental countries due to their size and dependence on [[sea lines of communication|sea]] and [[Line of communication|air lines of communication]].<ref name="Measures of Effectiveness">{{cite book | last = Perry | first = Walt L. |author2=Robert W. Button |author3=Jerome Bracken |author4=Thomas Sullivan |author5=Rand Corporation |author6=United States Navy |author7=Jonathan Mitchell | title = Measures of Effectiveness for the Information-age Navy | publisher = Rand Corporation | year = 2002 | pages = 7 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=VwI0WLby3WoC&pg=PA7&dq=%22island+country%22&lr=#PPA7,M1 | isbn = 0-8330-3139-2}}</ref> Many island countries are also vulnerable to predation by mercenaries and other foreign invaders,<ref name="Mercenary Holding Island Nation">{{cite news | last = WREN | first = CHRISTOPHER S. | title = Mercenary Holding Island Nation Seeks Deal | publisher = New York Times | date = December 9, 1989 | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=950DE3DB173CF93AA35751C1A96F948260 | accessdate = 2009-02-01}}</ref> although their isolation also makes them a difficult target.
==Natural resources== Many island countries rely heavily on [[Fish as food|fish]] for their main supply of food.<ref>{{cite web|title=Many of the world's poorest people depend on fish |publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations |date=2005-06-07 |url=http://www.fao.org/Newsroom/en/news/2005/102911/index.html |accessdate=2017-09-30 }}</ref> Some are turning to [[renewable energy]]—such as [[wind power]], [[hydropower]], [[geothermal power]] and [[biodiesel]] from [[Coconut oil|copra oil]]—to combat the rise in [[Petroleum|oil]] prices.<ref name="renewable energy">{{cite web |last = Xingwei |first = Huang |title = Pacific Islands countries switch to renewable energy source due to increasing fuel prices |publisher = |date = 2008-10-17 |url = http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-10/17/content_10210370.htm |accessdate = 2009-02-01 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150402144005/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-10/17/content_10210370.htm |archivedate = 2015-04-02 |df = }}</ref>
==Geography== Some island countries are more affected than other countries by [[climate change]], which produces problems such as reduced [[land use]], [[water scarcity]] and sometimes even resettlement issues. Some low-lying island countries are slowly being submerged by the rising water levels of the [[Pacific Ocean]].<ref name="Leader of disappearing island nation">{{cite web | title = Leader of disappearing island nation says climate change an issue of survival, not economics | date = June 5, 2008 | url = http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/06/05/asia/AS-GEN-New-Zealand-World-Environment-Day.php | accessdate = 2009-02-01}}</ref> Climate change also impacts island countries by causing natural disasters such as [[tropical cyclone]]s, hurricanes, [[flash flood]]s and [[drought]].<ref name="Climate change threatens food security">{{cite web | title = FAO: Climate change threatens food security of Pacific island countries | date = December 2, 2008 | url = http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90856/6544815.html | accessdate = 2009-02-01}}</ref> In 2011, the Center for Climate Change Law (CCCL) held a conference attended by 272 registrants from 39 island nations titled ''Legal Issues for Threatened Island Nations''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.earth.columbia.edu/articles/view/2826|title=Threatened Island Nations Conference - The Earth Institute - Columbia University|author=|date=|website=www.earth.columbia.edu|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref>
==Economics== Many island countries rely heavily on imports and are greatly affected by changes in the global economy.<ref name="cctv">{{cite web | title = Global economic crisis a concern for Pacific island countries | date = 2008-10-28 | url = http://www.cctv.com/program/bizchina/20081028/106856.shtml | accessdate = 2009-02-01}}</ref> Due to the nature of island countries their economies are often characterised by being smaller, relatively isolated from world trade and economy, more vulnerable to shipping costs, and more likely to suffer environmental damage to infrastructure; exceptions include Japan and the United Kingdom.<ref name="Trade Policy Course">{{cite web | title = WTO/FORSEC Trade Policy Course for Pacific island countries | date = 9 March 2001 | url = http://www.wto.org/english/news_e/news01_e/fiji_e.htm | accessdate = 2009-02-01}}</ref><ref name="NZ calls for global solutions">{{cite web |title = NZ calls for global solutions to problems faced by small island nations |date = 2005-01-18 |url = http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2005-01/18/content_2475179.htm |accessdate = 2009-02-01 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121024065854/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2005-01/18/content_2475179.htm |archivedate = 2012-10-24 |df = }}</ref><ref name="U.N. ambassador gives keynote">{{cite web | last = Garg | first = Sarika | title = U.N. ambassador gives keynote | url = http://www.thedp.com/article/1994/04/u.n._ambassador_gives_keynote | accessdate = 2017-09-05 }}</ref> The dominant industry for many island countries is [[tourism]].<ref name="tourist destinations">{{cite news | title = China enlists Pacific island countries as tourist destinations, XINHUA. | date = 10 August 2004 | url = http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-12915601_ITM | accessdate = 1 February 2009 | work=The America's Intelligence Wire}}</ref>
==Composition== Island countries are typically small with low populations, although some, like [[Indonesia]] and [[Japan]] are notable exceptions.<ref name="Wen pledges new aid to Pacific countries">{{cite web | title = Wen pledges new aid to Pacific countries | publisher = International Herald Tribune | date = April 5, 2006 | url = http://www.iht.com/articles/2006/04/05/news/pacific.php | accessdate = 2013-08-21}}</ref>
Some island countries are centred on one or two major islands, such as the [[United Kingdom]], [[Trinidad and Tobago]], [[New Zealand]], [[Cuba]], [[Bahrain]], [[Singapore]], [[Iceland]], [[Malta]], and [[Taiwan]]. Others are spread out over hundreds or thousands of smaller islands, such as [[Indonesia]], the [[Philippines]], [[The Bahamas]], [[Seychelles]], and the [[Maldives]]. Some island countries share one or more of their islands with other countries, such as the [[United Kingdom]] and the [[Republic of Ireland]]; [[Haiti]] and the [[Dominican Republic]]; and [[Indonesia]], which shares islands with [[Papua New Guinea]], [[Brunei]], [[East Timor]], and [[Malaysia]].
Geographically, the country of [[Australia]] is considered a [[continent]]al landmass rather than an island, covering the largest landmass of the [[Australia (continent)|Australian continent]]. In the past, however, it was considered an island country for tourism purposes<ref name="nla.gov.au">{{cite web | title = Australian Naval Defence | publisher = The Brisbane Courier | date = 24 July 1897 | url = http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/3655029 | accessdate = 2009-01-31 }}</ref> (among others) and is sometimes referred to as such.<ref name="China, Pacific island countries">{{cite web | title = China, Pacific island countries discuss cooperation at forum meeting | url = http://english.people.com.cn/200604/05/eng20060405_256086.html | accessdate = 2009-02-01}}</ref>
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Archipelagic state]] *[[Effects of climate change on island nations]] *[[Landlocked country]] *[[List of Caribbean island countries by population]] *[[List of island countries]] *[[List of islands by area]] *[[List of islands#Islands by country|List of islands]] (by country) *[[List of sovereign states and dependent territories in Oceania]] *[[List of sovereign states and dependent territories in the Indian Ocean]] *[[Microstate]] *[[City state]] *[[Pacific Islands Forum]] *[[Small Island Developing States]] *[[Thalassocracy]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist|39em}}
{{Authority control}}
{{Lists of countries and territories by continent}}
[[Category:Island countries| ]] [[Category:Political geography|Island nation]] [[Category:Country classifications]]
[[is:Eyríki]]

revision.comment: /* Muiuz kernei */
revision.text:
The '''''karnay''''' is a long trumpet with a mouthpiece.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pastimes of Central Asians. Musicians. A Man Playing a Karnay, a Long-necked Trumpet-like Instrument|url=http://www.wdl.org/en/item/10827|work=[[World Digital Library]]|accessdate=14 May 2014}}</ref> It is used in the music of [[Music of Iran|Iran]], [[Music of Tajikistan|Tajikistan]], and [[Music of Uzbekistan|Uzbekistan]], where it is considered a [[National instrument (music)|national instrument]]. {| style="width:200px; float:right; border:1px solid #ccc; background:#f9f9f9; font-size:88%; line-height:1.5em;" | [[Image:Karnaychi (karnay musicians) at the Didor International Film Festival, Dushanbe, Tajikistan - 20101012.ogg|thumb |300px |Musicians playing the karnay at the opening of the international film festival Didor in Dushanbe, Tajikistan on 12 October 2010.]] |} [[File:Разновидности Карная.JPG|thumb|235px|Versions of Karnay.]]
==Kernei== The ''kernei'' is a Kyrgyz wind musical instrument, which as well as the ''surnai'' ({{lang-fa|سرنای}}) was not modernised for ensembles or orchestras and exists in traditional form. It is used particularly for signaling or as a ceremonial instrument with a powerful sound and piercing timbre. There are two kinds of ''kernei'': the ''muiuz kernei'' (made from a [[mountain goat]] horn), and the ''jez kernei'' (made of copper or brass). Both of them are very different instruments, but they are combined by lack of playing apertures.<!--"combined by lack of playing apertures" doesn't mean anything in English. Please clarify.-->
==Muiuz kernei== [[File:Members of the Military Brass Band of Tajikistan with Karnays.jpg|thumb|Members of a Tajik Military Brass Band playing Karnays.]] The ''muiuz kernei'' is an ancient instrument made from a curved mountain goat horn, ranging in length between 30 and 40 cm. The instrument does not have a mouthpiece and gives only a few sounds of thick, soft timbre. The [[Military Brass Band of the Commandant Regiment of the Ministry of Defense of Tajikistan]] (the only military band in the world to use karnays) uses the Muiuz kernei.
==Jez kernei== The ''jez kernei'' is 1–2 m long longitudinal trumpet with/without a mouthpiece. Faucet diameter is 20 cm. The similarity between the ''jez kernei'' and the Uzbek and Uigur ''karnai'' is accounted by the territorial nearness of South Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan. The sound of Kernei is very strong, loud and intended for outdoor areas. Some time in the past the ''kernei'''s applied function was restricted by notification of important events, but today it is typically used for national holidays.
The separate group of Kyrgyz aerophones represent the instruments, which considerably yield the main kinds of folk wind instruments by quality of timbre and artistic importance. They can be called as noise instruments. They were not produced by people, they exist in the nature and produce neither musical nor artistic sounds. They include the ''chymyldak'' - produce squeak, ''yshkyryk'' - whistle, ''baryldak'' - under tongue aerophone, ''chynyrtky'' - hunter's quail call, ''jalbyrak'' - "explosive" aerophone.
==References== {{reflist}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.festivalofworldcultures.com/events/display.asp?eventid=189 |accessdate=April 26, 2008 |publisher=Festival of World Culture |work=Event Listings |title=Rhythms of Uzbekistan: Featuring Shod & Lyazgi |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080308051915/http://www.festivalofworldcultures.com/events/display.asp?eventid=189 |archivedate=March 8, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }} *{{cite web|url=http://www.korea.mfa.uz/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=1046&mode=thread&order=0&thold=0|accessdate=April 26, 2008|publisher=Embassy of Uzbekistan in Korea|date=August 9, 2007|title=‘Tashkent’ Musicians Capture Attention In UK, Gain Appraisal|quote=the magic sound of karnay (the Uzbek national music instrument)|author=IA Jahon}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{commons category|Karnay}} {{Iranian musical instruments}}
Persian script: hashkamelash kamelash lokimash habash

{{Multiple issues| {{unsourced|date=January 2016}}{{notability|Music|date=January 2016}} {{Orphan|date=November 2016}} }} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Midi lidi | image = | image_size = | landscape = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank --> | alt = | caption = | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Czech Republic]] | genre = [[Electro music|Electro]] | years_active = <!-- {{start date|YYYY}}–{{end date|YYYY}} (or –present) --> | label = | associated_acts = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | current_members = *Peter Mark *Prokop Holoubek *Marketa Lisa *Tomino Kelar | past_members = }} '''Midi lidi''' are a [[Czech republic|Czech]] [[Electro music|electro]] band, consisting of Petr Marek, Prokop Holoubek, Markéta Lisá, Tomino Kelar, and others. The group wrote music for [[Marek Najbrt]]'s films ''[[Protector (2009 film)|Protector]]'' and ''[[Polski film]]'', as well as the documentary film ''[[Czech Peace]]''. They also wrote the soundtrack for the series ''Kancelář Blaník'', which is hosted on the Czech internet television channel stream.cz
==Discography==
=== Albums === * ''[[:cs:Čekání na robota|Čekání na robota]]'' (2007), published [[X Production]] * ''Protektor'' (2009), [[soundtrack]] for the film ''[[Protector (2009 film)|Protector]]'' * ''[[:cs:Hastrmans, Tatrmans & Bubáks|Hastrmans, Tatrmans & Bubáks]]'' (2009), X Production * ''[[:cs:Operace „Kindigo!“|Operace "Kindigo!"]]'' (2011), X Production * ''Give Masterpiece a Chance!'' (2016), X Production
== References == <references />
== External links == {{Commons category|Midi lidi}} * [http://www.unarclub.cz/MidiLidi.html Oficial site]

page.title: NIOD Institute for War, Holocaust and Genocide Studies

revision.comment: put English first
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=February 2007}} {{Infobox organization | name = NIOD Institute for War, Holocaust and Genocide Studies | image = 002 (NIOD sign) 2016 (Herengracht 380-382, Amsterdam).png | map2 = | abbreviation = | motto = | predecessor = Netherlands Institute for War Documentation
Center for Holocaust and Genocide Studies | successor = | formation = 8 May 1945 | type = | purpose = NIOD’s area of work covers the 20th and 21st century, with a focus on research into the effects of wars, the Holocaust and other genocides on individuals and society.[http://www.niod.knaw.nl/en/about-niod About NIOD] | headquarters = [[Amsterdam]] | location = [[Netherlands]] | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | budget = | num_staff = 58 (49.61 [[Full-time equivalent|FTE]]) per 31 December 2014[http://www.niod.knaw.nl/nl/mediatag/jaarverslagen Annual Report (Jaarverslag) for 2014] | num_volunteers = | website = [http://www.niod.knaw.nl/en www.niod.knaw.nl/en] | remarks = | former name = }} The '''NIOD Institute for War, Holocaust and Genocide Studies''' ([[Dutch language|Dutch]]: ''NIOD Instituut voor Oorlogs-, Holocaust- en Genocidestudies'') is an [[organisation]] in the [[Netherlands]] which maintains archives and carries out [[history|historical]] studies into the [[Second World War]], the Holocaust and other genocides around the world, past and present. The institute was founded as a merger of the '''Netherlands Institute for War Documentation''' ([[Dutch language|Dutch]]: ''Nederlands instituut voor oorlogsdocumentatie'', NIOD, formerly '''National Institute for War Documentation''', [[Dutch language|Dutch]]: ''Rijksinstituut voor oorlogsdocumentatie'', RIOD) and the '''Center for Holocaust and Genocide Studies''' (CHGS).{{cite web| url=http://www.niod.knaw.nl/en/instituutsgeschiedenis.asp| title=A short history of the NIOD | date= | accessdate=25 July 2012 |author=| publisher=NIOD Institute for War, Holocaust and Genocide Studies }} It has been part of the [[Koninklijke Nederlandse Akademie van Wetenschappen|Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences]] since January 1, 1999. ==Duties== According to its website, the NIOD Institute is intended to: {{quote|Collect, manages, opens up and makes accessible archives and collections about the Second World War. Conduct academic research and publishes about it. Give information to government bodies and individual. Stimulate and organise debates and activities about war violence and processes that are at the basis of war violence.}} It administers the archives of the German occupation of the Netherlands and the Japanese occupation of the Dutch East Indies, as well as large collections of clandestine newspapers and pamphlets, photographs, books and articles.[https://www.knaw.nl/en/institutes/niod?set_language=en KNAW page on NIOD Institute for War, Holocaust and Genocide Studies] ==Studies and publications== The institute published ''Het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden in de Tweede Wereldoorlog'' ([[The Kingdom of the Netherlands During World War II]]) in fourteen volumes and 18,000 pages. The magnum opus of [[Loe de Jong]] is the standard reference on the history of the Netherlands during [[World War II]]. The NIOD had recently made an electronic edition of the entire work, available for downloading from 11 December 2011, licensed under creative commons CC BY 3.0.{{cite web |url= http://www.niod.knaw.nl/koninkrijk/|title= The Kingdom of the Netherlands During World War II|author= Loe de Jong|date= 1969–1991|work= |publisher= NIOD|accessdate=21 December 2011 | language=Dutch}} It also performed a study into the [[Srebrenica massacre]] of 1995, which led to the report [[Srebrenica: a ‘safe’ area]], which led to the resignation of the [[second cabinet of Wim Kok]]. ===Other publications=== * Post, Peter / Gijsbers, Harco: ''The Encyclopedia of Indonesia in the Pacific War''. Publisher: Brill, Leiden/Boston, 2010. {{ISBN|9789004168664}} * Withuis, Jolande / Mooij, Annet (eds.): ''The Politics of War Trauma, The Aftermath of World War II in Eleven European Countries''. Publisher: Aksant, Amsterdam, 2010. {{ISBN|9789052603711}} * Boender, Barbara / Haperen, Maria van / Üngör, Ugu: ''The Holocaust and other genocides. An introduction''. Publisher: Amsterdam University Press, Amsterdam, 2012. {{ISBN|9789089643810}} * Adler, Nanci: ''Keeping Faith with the Party: Communist Believers Return from the Gulag''. Publisher: Indiana University Press, Bloomington, 2012. {{ISBN|9780253357229}} * Keizer, Madelon de (ed.) / Bakker, Marjo (ed.) / Griffin, Roger (ed.): ''Fascism. Journal of Comparative Fascist Studies''. Publisher: Brill, Leiden, 2012. {{ISSN|2211-6257}} ==Gallery== {| border="0" cellpadding="5" cellspacing="0" align="center" |- |[[File:05 (NIOD) 2016 (Herengracht 380-382, Amsterdam).jpg|200px|Main entrance at Herengracht]] |[[File:04 (NIOD) 2016 (Herengracht 380-382, Amsterdam).jpg|200px|Exhibition space at the NIOD Institute for War, Holocaust and Genocide Studies]] |[[File:01 (NIOD) 2016 (Herengracht 380-382, Amsterdam).jpg|200px|NIOD Institute for War, Holocaust and Genocide Studies at Herengracht 380 in Amsterdam]] |[[File:NIOD study room.jpg|200px|Study room of the NIOD Institute for War, Holocaust and Genocide Studies]] |[[File:Amsterdam-NIOD edit-a-thon 29 November 2014 (19).JPG|200px|Courtyard next to the study room]] |} ==See also== *[[Centre for Historical Research and Documentation on War and Contemporary Society]] - an equivalent institution in Belgium ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.niod.knaw.nl/en Official Website (English language)] {{commons category|NIOD}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Archives in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Netherlands in World War II]] [[Category:Research institutes in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Historiography of the Netherlands]] [[Category:Research institutes established in 1945]] [[Category:1945 establishments in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Holocaust studies]] {{Netherlands-org-stub}} {{library-stub}}

revision.text:
{{See also|Index of India-related articles}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Use Indian English|date=June 2016}} {{double image|right|flag of India.svg|195|Emblem of India.svg|84|The [[flag of India]]|The [[Emblem of India]]}} [[File:India (orthographic projection).svg|right|188px]] [[File:IndiaEveryCityOMC.png|thumb|An enlargeable map of the cities of India]] The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to India: '''[[India]]''' – [[List of countries and outlying territories by total area|seventh-largest]] country by area, located on the [[Indian subcontinent]] in [[South Asia]]. India was home to the ancient [[Indus Valley Civilisation]], and is the birthplace of four world religions—[[Hinduism in India|Hinduism]], [[Sikhism in India|Sikhism]], [[History of Buddhism in India|Buddhism]], [[Statistics of Jainism|Jainism]]. India endured [[Colonial India|colonization]], eventually being [[British Raj|administered by the United Kingdom]] from the mid-19th century to the mid-20th century. India became an independent nation in 1947 after a [[Indian independence movement|struggle for independence]] that was mainly [[non-violent resistance]], led by influential figures like [[Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi|Mahatma Gandhi]], and underwent a violent [[Partition of India|partition]]. India is the [[List of countries by population|second-most populous]] country with [[Demographics of India|over 1.2 billion people]], and is also the most populous [[democracy]] in the world. {{TOC limit|limit=2}} == General reference == [[File:India-map-en.svg|thumb|An enlargeable basic map of India]] * Pronunciation: {{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɪ|n|d|i|ə}} * Common English country name:India * Official English country name:The Republic of India * Common [[endonym]](s): [[List of countries and capitals in native languages|Bharat]], [[Hindustan]] * Official endonym(s): [[List of official endonyms of present-day nations and states|Bharat Ganarajya]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectival]](s): [[Indian (disambiguation)|Indian]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): Indian * [[Etymology]]: [[Names for India|Names of India]] * [[International rankings of India]] * [[ISO country codes]]:IN, IND, 356 * [[ISO region codes]]:See [[ISO 3166-2:IN]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]:[[.in]] == Geography of India == {{Main|Geography of India}} * India is: ** a [[Indian subcontinent|subcontinent]] ** a country *** a [[megadiverse countries|megadiverse country]] * Location: ** [[Eastern Hemisphere]] ** [[Northern Hemisphere]] *** [[Eurasia]] **** [[Asia]] of Punjab (India)|Demographics of Punjab]] # [[Demographics of Rajasthan]] # [[Demographics of Sikkim]] # [[Demographics of Tamil Nadu]] # [[Demographics of Tripura]] # [[Demographics of Uttar Pradesh]] # [[Demographics of Uttarakhand]] # [[Demographics of West Bengal]] }} == Government and politics of India == {{main|Government of India|Politics of India}} [[File:New Delhi government block 03-2016 img3.jpg|thumb|SansadBhavan]] * [[Form of government]]: [[Sovereign state|Sovereign]] [[Socialist state|socialist]] [[Secular state|secular]] [[federation|federal]] [[parliamentary system|parliamentary]] [[multi-party system|multi-party]] [[representative democracy|representative]] [[Democracy|democratic]] [[republic]]. ** [[Sovereign state|Sovereign]] – this means an independent nation. ** [[Socialist state|Socialist]] – this implies social and economic equality for all Indian citizens. This guarantees equal opportunity and equal social status. The government attempts to reduce economic inequality by reducing concentration of wealth. ** [[Secular state|Secular]] – practices separation of church and state.This implies freedom to choose your religion. The state gives every citizen the right to practice and propagate a religion of his choice, and also right to reject all religions. The state treats all religions as equal and there is no official state religion. ** [[Democracy|Democratic]] – this means the government is democratically elected, and the head of the government (prime minister) is elected by the people. ** [[Republic]] – this means the head of the state (president) is not a hereditary King or Queen but indirectly elected by the people.http://www.indiaquickfacts.com/content/india-government-indian-democracy * [[Capital (political)|Capital]] of India: [[New Delhi]] * [[Elections in India]] ** [[Indian general election, 1951|1951]] {{!}} [[Indian general election, 1957|1957]] {{!}} [[Indian general election, 1962|1962]] {{!}} [[Indian general election, 1967|1967]] {{!}} [[Indian general election, 1971|1971]] {{!}}
